Graphical abstract In this work, deep oxidative desulfurization was attained using a new kind MoO3 modified magnetic catalysts, in which metal organic framework (MOF-199) as supports and the magnetic Fe3O4 added to provide the extra character for increasing practical use value. The characterization of the as-designed catalysts were assessed by FT-IR, XRD, SEM, TPR and XPS analyses. To be noted, various morphologies of MoO3 were used to form the final products and compared to discuss their influences on the ODS performance in this work. Among them, the Fe@Mo-4@MOF, containing the fibroid MoO3, showed an excellent catalytic performance to the ultra-deep oxidative desulfurization in 45 min, which was mainly attributed to the special morphology of MoO3, providing the higher contact area with the DBT to increase the ODS efficiency. Moreover, the possible mechanism was proposed to illustrate the ODS process and only slight decrease of DBT removal was observed after 15 recycling times. Keywords Various morphologies of MoO3 Fe3O4 magnetic properties Metal-organic framework Oxidative desulfurization Recycling times 1 Introduction In recent years, the major source of air pollution and acid rain are mainly attributed to the exhaust gases, containing SOx, which have great dangers to our human bodies [1–3]. Thus, a growing number of attentions has been paid on, especially for the deep desulfurization, to produce the much more cleaning fuels [4,5]. However, the conventional hydrodesulfurization (HDS) process was limited to use to achieve the ultra-low sulfur levels, for the significantly low reactivity on the polyaromatic sulfur compounds (for example, DBT and its derivates). Besides, the high cost, such as the high pressure and temperature needed, was also another factor for their widespread use [6–8]. Thus, an alternative technology is urgent desirable and the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) has been in fore choose, which could take place under the mild conditions, as well as the high efficiency on the most refractory sulfur compounds [9,10]. During the oxidative desulfurization process, the DBT (as an example) could be oxidized to the corresponding sulfones easily and removed by the simple extractive or adsorptive operation [11]. Therefore, the ODS technology could be regarded as a potential method to achieve the ultra-deep desulfurization [12,13]. Among the previous studies, plenty of catalysts have been based on the ionic liquid [14,15], organic acids [16] or the heteropolyacids [17,18]. All these catalysts own their unique characters, but the shortcomings also exposed the practical application value. The biggest problems for ionic liquids and organic acids are centered on the separation and reconversion from the system after the end of reaction, while heteropolyacids are from the synthetic cost. Therefore, for the actual industrial production, the kind of low-cost, highly efficient, easily recycled, as well as the environmental-friendly catalyst are badly in need. To be pleased that, metal oxides, owing to various structures, unique physical and chemical properties, have caught our attention deeply [5,19–22]. While among them, MoO3, with highly catalytic performance, structural variability, as well as low cost, has been widely used as catalysts in petroleum, chemical and environmental fields in recent years [23,24]. Meanwhile, to prevent the loss of MoO3 during the reaction, modified MoO3 catalysts with different supports have also been studied and plenty of them were used in the oxidative desulfurization fields. Bita Mokhtari et al. [25] have synthesized a kind of catalyst with the molybdenum oxides on mesoporous silica gel (MoO3/SG) into the deep extractive oxidative desulfurization. About 99.9 % of sulfur compounds in real diesel was selectively and removed after 90 min with 5 wt% MoO3 loaded in. The result was mainly attributed to the sufficiently larger pore diameter and higher surface area of the supports, good distribution of the active species to benefit the higher catalytic performance together. Zahra Dini et al. [26] were focus on the functionalized CNTs to graft MoO3 as a new kind of catalysts and have evaluated them under oxidative desulfurization of model oil in the presence of H2O2 as oxidant. The best DBT conversion was obtained under the carboxyl functional groups on the CNTs, indicating the higher electron density leaded into could increase the catalytic performance. Xiaoyu Yao et al. [27] used the sample one-step method to prepare a supported MoOxNPs with grapheme-analogous boron nitride (g-BN) and could still reach 98.0 % after 11 times recycling experiments to remove DBT. Ming Zhang et al. [28] found an excellent 4,6-DMDBT removal efficiency on molybdenum-containing dendritic mesoporous silica spheres and could up to 100 % in 40 min with a low dosage of oxidant. Guangxue Yang et al. [29] have been synthesized the mesoporous silicoaluminophosphate catalyst by using a green and low-cost sucrose as template, a/h-MoO3/C2-S-11. Different MoO3 crystalline phrases in catalysts showed various catalytic results, and α-MoO3/C2-S-11 exhibited an excellent oxidative desulfurization performance and more favorable TOF value. Moreover, the structural and morphological differences of MoO3 showed various sensitivity leading to a special influence and to date, nanoparticles, nanobelts, hollow spheres and so forth have been produced. What is more, suitable fixing of active species is another essential and MOF as a support is widely researched [30,31], but little researches with magnetic Fe3O4 added to contribute to separation easily after reaction [32–34], let alone the various morphological MoO3 in the above system for the oxidative desulfurization. Inspired by the above findings, this paper was mainly investigated on the different morphologies of MoO3 in as-designed magnetic catalysts for the deep oxidative desulfurization, combining the magnetic Fe3O4 to achieve the highly efficiency in recycling times. Various morphologies of MoO3 could be obtained under the simple methods at first, and then further mixed with Fe3O4. Following the coating operation by the metal organic framework (MOF-199 chosen as the excellent properties described in previous work [35]), the as-designed new kind catalysts were obtained, named Fe3O4@MoO3@MOF-199, abbreviation Fe@Mo@MOF. Then, the catalytic performance of the catalysts was evaluated in the oxidative desulfurization process of the DBT removal from the model and real oil, respectively, aiming to achieve the ultra-low clean fuels. 2 Experiments 2.1 Materials All the reagents used in the preparation of the composite materials were analytical purity, namely cupric acetate (Cu(CH3COO)2) (Xi’an Chemical Works), ammonium molybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·H2O) and trimesic acid (H3BTC) (Aladdin), potassium phosphate (K3PO4), nitric acid (HNO3), chromic chloride (CrCl3) and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) (Adamas), DMF (Tianjing Chemical Works). The chemicals for desulfurization experiments, 4,6-DMDBT, DBT, BT (J&K technology) and n-dodecane (Tianjing Fuchen chemical reagent factory), were used as received. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts FT-IR measurements were collected on the EQUINOX-55 FTIR spectrometer (German Bruker Company) with a spectral resolution of 2 cm−1 in a wave number range of 400−4000 cm−1. Power X-ray diffraction patterns were determined on a Rigaku, D/max-2550/PC (Rigaku, Japan) using Cu Kα radiation and the scan ranges were from 2−70° with 0.02°/step. BET analysis was conducted on TriStar II 3020 with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, and before the measurement to degassing at 423 K for 6 h. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on TM3000, operating in “low vacuum” mode. This required the powder catalysts crushed and dispersed in ethanol and then dropped onto conductive adhesive, which volatilized under natural conditions. The elements content in catalysts were determined on I coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) of an IRIS Advantage spectrometer. The TPR plot was logged using an on-line data acquisition system. X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) was obtained using K-Alpha on PHI-1600 from US Thermo Electron Corporation. Vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) was generated using an LDJ-9500 instrument with largest measuring magnetic field intensity 10 KOe. 2.3 Catalyst synthesis MoO3: Mo-1: MoO3 was obtained by directly calcining (NH4)6Mo7O24 at 500 °C for 240 min. Mo-2: Firstly, 0.62 g (NH4)6Mo7O24 was dissolved in a mixture (50 mL) with the same volumes ratio deionized water and ethanol. After the vigorous magnetic stirring for 30 min, 0.2 g K3PO4 was added and the HNO3 (2.2 mol/L) was used to adjust pH to 1.5. Following stirred for 30 min to the homogeneous mixing, the final solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and reacted at 180 °C for 20 h. The synthesized MoO3 was collected and washed with water and ethanol for three times, respectively, and then dried at 60 °C for 20 h. Mo-3: 1.85 g (NH4)6Mo7O24 and 0.25 g CrCl3 were dissolved in 40 mL distilled water and 10 mL ethanol, respectively. Mixing the two solutions and stirring for another 1 h, HNO3 (2.2 mol/L) was added dropwise to adjust the solution to PH = 1.5, and then transferring them to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The final material was obtained after reacting at 180 °C for 24 h and then washing with water and ethanol for three times, finally dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. Mo-4: The same synthetic process as described for Mo-3 above, except the PVP was used to exchange CrCl3 as the inducer. MoO3@Fe3O4: MoO3@Fe3O4 was achieved by grinding-calcination method and the detailed process was as below: 0.2 g Fe3O4 and a certain amount MoO3 were ground completely to mix for 30 min, and then the mixture was burned in a crucible at 450 °C for 3 h. Fe3O4@MoO3@MOF-199 (Fe@Mo@MOF): 0.03 g as-prepared MoO3@Fe3O4 was mixed with H3BTC 0.10 g (0.48 mmol) and Cu(CH3COO)2 0.17 g (0.86 mmol), ground under several drops of water for 30 min. Then, the mixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave with 10 mL DMF in the bottle and the final product was obtained after reacted at 100 °C for 12 h. Then the mixture was washed with DMF, following the solvent exchanged operation with methanol and dichloromethane for 24 h in order and dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. For the four kinds of MoO3 used in, the relevant final products, named Fe@Mo-1@MOF, Fe@Mo-2@MOF, Fe@Mo-3@MOF and Fe@Mo-4@MOF, were obtained. 2.4 Oxidative desulfurization procedure Model oil, with the sulfur contents of 500, 1000, 1500 and 2000 ppm, were prepared under the simple dissolution operation, in which a certain amount of DBT were mixed with n-dodecane. In a typical run, the certain amount catalyst was added to 100 ml model oil in a three-necked bottle, connected with a pump to flow into air as oxidant, a magnetic stirrer and a reflux condenser. Following the consecutive flow the air and stirring, the oxidative desulfurization process began. During the reaction, the upper layer after centrifuged at every 15 min was collected and the sulfur compound concentration was detected quickly by gas chromatography (Agilent GC 6890) and the relative value was calculated under the Eq. (1) below (C0 and C stand for the initial and final concentration of S-compounds, respectively, η is the DBT conversion). (1) η= C O - C / C O × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characteristics of the Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts Fig. 1 illustrates the IR spectrum of four kinds MoO3 and Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts. In Fig. 1a, three distinct bands appear at 620, 850 and 980 cm−1, which correspond to the symmetrical and asymmetric stretching of bridge OMoO and weak microcrystallities of MoO3. After introducing the magnetic Fe3O materials, the new peaks, around 503 and 1640 cm−1, appear in accordance with the Fe-O stretching vibration and the absorbed H2O molecules in the samples (Fig. 1b). Besides, the bands emerged at 1460, 2800 and 2920 cm−1 clearly demonstrate the MOF-199 introduced in successfully, which are assigned to the carbonyl stretching vibration bands in carboxyl groups and CH2 groups [35]. Therefore, the as-designed Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts could be proved following the existence of different parts in (Fe3O4, MoO3 and MOF-199) and the combination with other characteristic methods below together to confirm the actual structure information. Fig. 2 exhibits the XRD patterns of the four kinds MoO3 in Fig. 2a and Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts with various MoO3 above in Fig. 2b. The characteristic diffraction peaks of MoO3 match well with the standard PDF card of #05-0508 (space group: Pbnm (62); lattice constants: a = 0.3962 nm, b-1.3858 nm, c = 0.3697 nm), indicating the different morphologies structure of them could not effect on the crystalline data. Moreover, the well-defined diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 (in accord with the #88-0866) and the strong peak at 2θ = 8° (belongs to MOF-199 [36]) reveal the good crystallization of Fe3O4, MOF-199 and MoO3, which were not destroyed during the synthesis process. In other word to say, they have maintained their own characteristic peaks in the final catalysts of Fe@Mo@MOF samples. These results could be in good agreement with FT-IR analysis, suggesting the successful introduced of the three parts in the final products (Table 1 ). The TPR plot, which could prove the MoO3 active species in the Fe@Mo@MOF catalyst, is shown in Fig. 3 (chosen Mo-4 as an example) and the detailed value for the four catalysts are in Table 2 . Taking Mo-4 as an example to discuss, the peak around 703 K is attributed to the reduction of Mo6+ to Mo4+ in dispersed polymeric structure, while 852 K is from the MoO3 crystallites. To note, a broad peak at 1158 K, which is associated with a further reduction of the first and second peaks above, could also be influenced by the Fe3O4 and MOF-199 introducing. The results from the TPR plot could indicate the presence of MoO3 in detail and shown no slight change following the different morphologies [37]. The specific surface area of samples (shown in Fig. 4 and Table 2), measured by BET method, are 1264 m2/g (MOF-199), 423 m2/g, 420 m2/g, 405 m2/g and 400 m2/g (Fe@Mo@MOF), respectively. The rather low surface area value of Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts compared with the pure MOF-199 could indicate the more Fe3O4@MoO3 into the pores of MOF, under the result of the self-assembly. As for the pore volume, the value of 0.52 cm3/g for MOF decreased down to 0.21 cm3/g of Fe@Mo-4@MOF (the lowest one), also suggesting the Fe3O4@MoO3 introduced inside the pores successfully and the lowest one for Fe@Mo-4@MOF proves to be the most active species amount in. Moreover, the slight bigger on pore diameter of catalysts could be attributed to the enlargement of Fe3O4@MoO3 filled in, which could also together verify the as-designed catalyst structure clearly with the other methods mentioned. Besides, the actual Mo content in different samples are also shown in Table 2, which was calculated by ICP analysis results. Fig. 5 a–d show the SEM images of various MoO3 morphologies and Fig. 5e–h are the relative four catalysts of Fe@Mo@MOF. The structures of MoO3 have been observed differently, for the spherical Mo-1, clubbed Mo-2 and Mo-3, and fibroid Mo-4. After compositing the final Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts, the hybrid products present the balls with uniform size and the diameter around 0.2−0.5 um. The phenomenon mainly is attributed to the result of spherical Fe3O4 in the middle and the MOF-199 self-assembled surrounding outside, while MoO3 active species also in the pores to achieve the catalytic performance. The designed structure could be proved clearly by SEM images, even under different various morphologies of MoO3 in and then further to discuss their influences on ODS process. XPS measurements were carried out to the further investigate the surface composition and chemical state of the Fe@Mo-4@MOF (as an example). As shown in Fig. 6 a, the image shows the catalyst comprised by Fe, Mo, Cu, C and O elements, in which C 1s shows obvious from the carbon framework of MOF-199 at 284.5 eV. Fig. 6b presents the double Fe 2p peaks, located at 723.6 eV and 726.5 eV, belonging to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Fe3O4. Mo 3d spectrum in Fig. 6c consists of two obvious peaks at 232.1 eV and 235.6 eV, corresponding to the Mo6+ in MoO3. Moreover, two peaks at 934.8 eV and 954.8 eV in Fig. 6d are assigned to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively, causing from the MOF-199 with the central metal ion. The magnetic properties of Fe@Mo@MOF samples were measured and the results were shown in Fig. 7 . The saturation magnetization value are 6.8, 6.2, 5.3 and 5.8 emu/g for the four catalysts, respectively. The rather low value compared with the pure Fe3O4 of 28.5 emu/g indicates the MOF materials coating outside, in accordance with the designed structure. Besides, there is no remanent magnetism detected, proving an intrinsic superparamagnetism feature due to the presence of the magnetic core. However, for the magnetism observed above and even the low value of the final products, they all could still be readily separated from the reaction system for the recycling experiments in the further ODS process below, only by the simple external magnet used. 3.2 Catalytic oxidative desulfurization of Fe@Mo@MOF catalyst 3.2.1 Contributions of Fe@Mo@MOF structure to desulfurization efficiency To investigate the oxidative desulfurization process on four kinds of Fe@Mo@MOF catalyst, 2000 ppm of initial sulfur content was employed. As listed in Table 3 , Fe3O4 and MOF-199 are as low as 3.5 % and 33.2 % in 120 min, respectively, which mainly due to the limited contribution to the ODS process and MOF-199 might show the adsorption desulfurization efficiency [7,38]. At the same time, the DBT conversion is rather low under the pure MoO3, mainly because of the limitation of mass transfer and the original low efficiency itself [39]. Besides, even 94.8 % is obtained for Mo@MOF, only 90.2 % after the second time recycling experiment, which could be a strong evidence to testify the low using efficiency without Fe3O4 added. While Fe@Mo-1@MOF, Fe@Mo-2@MOF, Fe@Mo-3@MOF and Fe@Mo-4@MOF demonstrate a higher conversion: 95.1 %, 97.3 %, 98.9 % and 100 %, respectively. Compared with the catalysts each other, the Fe@Mo-4@MOF shows a best performance, owning the ultra-deep desulfurization efficiency using a less reaction time of 45 min. The result mainly relates to the potential structural characteristics of MoO3 active species, leading to be filled into the pores as much as possible to play an important role in the ODS process under the same conditions compared with other three catalysts. The morphology of Mo-4 exhibits a kind of fiber cluster, having a maximum contact area with the DBT to exert the catalytic performance as well as uniformly dispersed in, which could help to increase the catalytic desulfurization on the DBT removal together. Due to the best performance in ODS process, Fe@Mo-4@MOF was chosen to do the further investigation. Table 4 shows a comparison of different MoO3 active species in catalyst system used in ODS process. As can be noticed in Entry 1–3, the much longer reaction time was used for MoO3/Al2O3 and three of them showed a relative poor desulfurization efficiency following Al3O4 as the supports. For the higher efficiency, MoVI/SAPO-11 in Entry 5 spent much longer time, 240 min, to achieve and MoO3/SG in Entry 4 and O-MWNT/MoO3 in Entry 6 used lesser, but even more after compared with our present work. Besides, when Ni modified MoO3 used in Entry 7, more oxidant should be used to obtain a higher efficiency. Thus, remarkably, the MoO3 modified magnetic catalyst, Fe@Mo@MOF, shows outstanding not only the less reaction time, but also the catalytic desulfurization performance. 3.2.2 The optimal reaction conditions on the Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts on the DBT conversion 3.2.2.1 MoO3 loading amount To investigate the influence on the MoO3 active species in the Fe@Mo@MOF systems, the various loading amount, range from 10 % to 18 %, was discussed (Fig. 8 , Table S1). For the obvious desulfurization efficiency changed, the short loading interval was chosen and used the small span range. However, less than 95 % of DBT conversion was achieved when the loading amount at 10 %, 12 % and 14 %, only 52.3 %, 75.6 % and 92.6 %. Then, the complete desulfurization effect has been achieved following the gradually increasing on the loading amount. When the 16 % and 18 % MoO3 loaded in the system, the DBT conversion increased remarkably, mainly due to the more active species introduced in, the higher collision probability between them with the DBT occurred, which leading to the much higher desulfurization efficiency. Therefore, 16 % is chosen as the optimal loading amount under the economic efficiency consideration. 3.2.2.2 Catalyst amount As shown in Fig. 9 , it is clear for the desulfurization efficiency changed following the various amount of catalyst used. Under 0.3 and 0.4 g/L added into the reaction system, the DBT conversion are less than 90 % even until 90 min, while it reaches up to 100 % quickly under the catalyst amount of 0.5 g/L. When the amount increases continually, deep desulfurization is also achieved in 45 min, with a shorter reaction time. Because higher mcatalyst/moil molar ratio could provide the much more opportunity for DBT and catalysts to contact, the final desulfurization results would directly be increased. However, the desulfurization performance has been unchanged even continuous increasing the catalyst amount, mainly due to the fixed quantity of DBT in system needed to be oxidized. Therefore, for the economic factors, 0.5 g/L catalyst is chosen as the optimal amount in the subsequent experiments. 3.2.2.3 Agitation rate Fig. 10 a reveals the effects of agitation rate on the DBT removal and 200, 300, 400, 500 rpm were chosen to investigate. The results indicates that the complete desulfurization efficiency could obtain after 45 min under the agitation rate of 400 rpm, which was compared with the slower rate of 200 and 300 rpm, with 75.6 % and 83.2 %, respectively. At a higher agitation rate of 500 rpm, the sulfur removal decreased from 100 % to 92.3 % obviously, which might lie in the volatilization of solvent under the quicker agitation rate, and showed the adverse effect in ODS process. In spite of it, the study on the agitation rate could help to reduce the effect of mass transfer resistance in the reaction system. Thus, 400 rpm is chosen as the best one for the following researches. 3.2.2.4 Air flowing rate The effect of the air flowing rate is shown in Fig. 10 and under the absence of oxygen in air as oxygen, the rather low DBT conversion was obtained, suggesting the important role of oxidant during the desulfurization process. As shown in Fig. 10b, the oxidative performance increases following the enhanced air flowing rate, from 500 L/min to 1100 L/min with every 200 L/min span. When the flowing rate is less than 700 L/min, the relative lower desulfurization efficiency has been obtained, only 53.2 % (500 L/min) and 70.8 % (700 L/min) in 75 min. The result is mainly attributed to the lack of oxidant in the reaction system with the much more DBT needed to be oxidized. Meanwhile, when the flowing rate is up to 900 L/min, the corresponding DBT conversion enhances to 100 % in 45 min, with a shorter reaction time to gain a deep desulfurization efficiency. However, the continuous increased flowing rate could also achieve the same ultra-deep desulfurization result, as the rate up to 1100 L/min. Therefore, comprehensive consideration, 900 L/min is chosen as the optimal air flowing rate for the following researches. 3.2.2.5 Various sulfur compounds As expected, the nature of the substrates is an important factor to affect the real sulfur DBT conversion in the desulfurization system. Thus, the catalytic reactivity on different sulfur compounds was investigated, chosen widely existed in diesel: benzothiophene (BT) and 4, 6-dimethyl-dibenzothiophene (4, 6-DMDBT) as the representative substrates. As revealed in Fig. 11 , model oil with the highest sulfur compounds conversion for the DBT, and then 4, 6-DMDBT, BT at last, in which the order of DBT > 4, 6-DMDBT > BT with 100 %, 90.3 % and 78.8 % under the same reaction conditions. The results could clearly prove that the oxidation of sulfur compounds is in accordance with the effect on electrophilic addition and steric hindrance effect together [3,17]. For the electron density of S atoms decreasing following the order of 4, 6-DMDBT (5.760) > DBT (5.758) > BT (5.739) and the steric hindrance effect of two methyl groups on the 4, 6-DMDBT showing the inhibiting effect together, we have obtained the above sulfur compounds conversion order above. 3.2.2.6 Initial sulfur contents To study the various DBT concentration for the ODS process, 500 ppm, 1000 ppm, 1500 ppm and 2000 ppm were used in the system, shown in Fig. 12 . It is clear that the DBT conversion is significantly elevated by the increasing initial sulfur compound contents, obtaining the 98.5 %, 99.1 %, 99.5 % and 100 %, respectively. However, more than 98 % of DBT conversion could be achieved under the obvious different initial contents used, though the various effects occurred in each time period. Thus, the conclusion is that the initial sulfur contents have little impact on the efficiency of ODS under the Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts, mainly for the final value of DBT conversion, and 2000 ppm is chosen as the research object for the higher efficiency rate obtained under the same reaction node, compared with other three shown obviously in Fig. 12. 3.2.2.7 Reaction temperature The catalytic performances on the Fe@Mo-4@MOF catalyst were compared under various temperature, ranging from 30 °C to 60 °C. As shown in Fig. 13 a, the DBT conversion remarkably improves from 52.3 % for 30 °C to the 100 % for 50 °C, and then maintains the 100 % efficiency even keeping increasing the reaction temperature. This phenomenon is mainly attributed to the more formation of active species following the increased temperature, that is to say, the enhanced collision possible for them to show a higher desulfurization performance. However, the extremely high temperature could cause the volatilization of solvent and decrease the concentration of active species, thus, it could use to explain the reason why the decrease of DBT conversion when reached up to 60 °C. Besides, the reaction kinetics is the vital parameter to explain the oxidation of DBT and the values of the apparent reaction rate constant k under different reaction temperature was calculated following the Eq. (2), based on the slope of the linear of t ∼ -ln(Ct/Co). The k increases in the order: 30 °C < 40 °C < 50 °C and the straight lines in all cases (shown in Fig. 13b) results the oxidative reactions following the pseudo-first-order kinetics. A linear relationship is also obtained by the plot of –Ink versus 1/T, in which k is gained from the above equation, and the activation energy (Ea) is estimated from Eq. (3). Ea = 21.3 kJ mol−1 is obvious lower than those of the previous works [41,48,49], proving the easier react for the DBT removal under the Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts. (2) - ln C C o = k t (3) I n k = I n A - E a R T 3.2.3 Catalytic application of Fe@Mo@MOF in real diesel To test the potential value in industrial application of Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts, the catalytic oxidative desulfurization performance was investigated in the real diesel. According to the data from Table 5 , the properties of diesel before and after are clear to do the comparison. It is obvious that the total sulfur content in real diesel decreased from 1.21 % to 0.05 %, and DBT content of 2300 ppm to zero, while other numerous properties remained unaffected. The results above could demonstrate the better useful value of the kind of Fe@Mo@MOF catalysts for the industrial applications. 3.2.4 Recycling performance and stability of the Fe@Mo@MOF catalyst Repeated experiments have carried out to investigate the recycling performance on the ODS process (Fig. 14 ), which is an important index of them in the practical industrial applications. For the next cycle, the reaction was performed with the reused catalyst and fresh model oil added under the same reaction conditions. It is obvious that after up to 15 times recycling experiments, the DBT conversion was still kept with the slight decreased, which could prove the as-designed catalyst a potential value of using. At the beginning of first 4 recycling times, 100 % DBT conversion was maintained and it decreased to 99 % even after the 10 times. Meanwhile, the final desulfurization efficiency was still more than 95 %, still with a relative high performance, owning an excellent use value in the actual applications. The FT-IR spectrum (Fig. 14b) showed the characteristic bands were still preserved compared with the original one, except for the new peak at 1250 cm−1 for SO in sulfones, and XRD spectrum (Fig. 14c) with no noticeable change in the crystalline structures. Typically, the possible reason for the reduction is that the oxidative products of sulfones have been enriched continuously following the cycling times, instead of the active species leached off. In other words, the stability of catalyst is of importance in the ODS process for the several times recycling used, and the as-designed Fe@Mo@MOF in this work just so, which could widen a view of this kind catalysts in the oxidative desulfurization technology to the further researches. 3.3 Probable mechanism of catalytic oxidant process It is necessary to propose a mechanism for the explanation of catalytic oxidative desulfurization process under the Fe@Mo@MOF catalyst and qualitative researches on the ODS products were measured by GC–MS to help to clear the mechanism. As the comparison, the fresh oil was analyzed firstly by GC–MS, and then, after the typical run under the optimal reaction conditions, the catalysts were collected by external magnet simply and the filtrate was remained to test following washed with acetonitrile. As shown in Fig. 15 a, the strong peaks exhibits at 2.45 min and 7.40 min in fresh oil due to the existence of n-dodecane (as the standard) and DBT in the solvent, and no other peaks are found. While finishing the reaction, in Fig. 15b, no DBT peak appears, but a new peak around 9.85 min has been found in the GC–MS analysis results, which is attributed to the DBTO2 products. From the above results, the mechanism might come down to the two steps below: Firstly, DBT molecules are adsorbed on the surface of catalyst with the electrostatic attraction. As for the high oxidation state and Lewis acid sites, the active species of peroxometallic intermediates have been formed following the introduction of air as oxidant to the MoO bond, in which Mo6+ turning to Mo4+ [45–47]. And then, the peroxometallic intermediates with high electrophilic activity attack S atoms of DBT to form the corresponding DBTO and DBTO2 quickly [43,44]. From the GC–MS analysis and the proposed mechanism, it could demonstrate that the DBT could be oxidized completely to the relative sulfones under the Fe@Mo@MOF catalyst and air as oxidant. Meanwhile, the sulfones attached on the catalysts are carried off from the reaction system under the external magnet simply, for endowing potential properties when the catalysts are initial designed, and the catalysts could be reused after washing several times. 4 Conclusion In summary, an efficient and friendly oxidative desulfurization catalyst, MoO3 modified magnetic catalysts, has been achieved, using the metal organic framework (MOF-199) as supports and the magnetic Fe3O4 added to provide the extra character for increasing practical use value. To note, various morphologies of MoO3 have been used to form catalysts and compared to discuss their influence on the ODS performance at first. Among them, the Fe@Mo-4@MOF, containing the fibroid MoO3, showed an excellent ODS result, which could reach up to 100 % DBT conversion in 45 min under the reaction conditions: MoO3 loading amount = 16 %, m (catalyst)=0.5 g/L, T = 50 °C, air flowing rate = 900 L/min, agitation rate=400 rpm, initial sulfur content = 2000 ppm. The obvious excellent result under Fe@Mo-4@MOF could be mainly attributed to the special morphologies of MoO3 used to provide the higher contact area of final catalyst to the DBT molecular. Besides, the possible mechanism was proposed to illustrate the ODS process and GC–MS analysis attended to explain the oxidative products. This kind catalyst could retain the highly desulfurization efficiency after 15 recycling times, indicating a stable and useful catalyst in the ODS process, even in the real industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: In this work, deep oxidative desulfurization was attained using a new kind MoO3 modified magnetic catalysts, in which metal organic framework (MOF-199) as supports and the magnetic Fe3O4 added to provide the extra character for increasing practical use value. The characterization of the as-designed catalysts were assessed by FT-IR, XRD, SEM, TPR and XPS analyses. To be noted, various morphologies of MoO3 were used to form the final products and compared to discuss their influences on the ODS performance in this work. Among them, the Fe@Mo-4@MOF, containing the fibroid MoO3, showed an excellent catalytic performance to the ultra-deep oxidative desulfurization in 45 min, which was mainly attributed to the special morphology of MoO3, providing the higher contact area with the DBT to increase the ODS efficiency. Moreover, the possible mechanism was proposed to illustrate the ODS process and only slight decrease of DBT removal was observed after 15 recycling times.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic oxidation of DBT for ultra-deep desulfurization under MoO3 modified magnetic catalyst: The comparison influence on various morphologies of MoO3
